question: Which is not a variable of MDRD (Modification of Diet in Renal Disease) formula?
exp: TEST: 1. CKD - EPI - cystatin C method (BEST); Cystatin - C is produced by nucleated cells 2. Modification of diet in renal disease formula GFR= 186. 3 x (serum creatinine level ( mg/dl))-1. 154 x age-0. 203 x ( 0. 742 if female ) x (1. 21 if black) 3. Cockroft Gault formula 4. Creatinine clearance 5. Inulin clearance

question: The term end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is considered appropriate when GFR is:
exp: CKD Stage GFR Level (mL/min/1. 73m2) G1 > 90 G2 60-89 HTN develops in this stage G3 30-59 Anemia develops in this stage G4 15-29 Acidosis, Hyperkalemia G5 < 15 (End stage renal disease) Uraemia develops Albuminuria A1 3-30 mg/g A2 30-300 A3 > 300

question: Acute auto-graft rejection occurs within?
exp: Hypersensitivity reaction Time 1. Hyperacute II Minutes 2. Acute IV <6 months 3. Chronic IV >6 months

question: Which of the following is not a feature of Chronic Renal Failure?
exp: Choice A and D In CRF vitamin D3 production is low. This leads to low serum calcium and resultant secondary hyperparathyroidism. The increased PTH will increase the resorption of bones leading to osteitis cystica fibrosa Choice B Due to hyperphosphatemia, the increased phosphate chelates with calcium- | incidence of calcification of coronary aeries, heart valves and hence the less availability of calcium can explain the osteomalacia.

question: Which drug can be used in patients of cardio-renal syndrome?
The triad of 'saturnine gout' + hypertension + renal failure is seen in?
exp: Saturnine gout Cause - Lead toxicity Symptoms - Symptoms of lead toxicity precede the development of gout. Hence patient will have anemia, basophilic stippling of RBC, abdominal pain and nerve palsy The damage to kidney will lead to hypertension and progressive renal malfunction. Knee joint involvement is more common than MTP involvement in saturnine gout

question: Dementia in a patient with chronic renal failure with chronic hemodialysis is due to?
exp: Patients undergoing long-term dialysis acquire dialysis dementia. Dialysis dementia -leading cause is A-Beta 2 amyloid deposition. But it is not given in choices. A-Beta amyloid deposition is seen with Alzheimer's disease and hence is ruled out. Aluminium toxicity either from aluminum in the dialysate or consumption of aluminium containing drugs is linked to the pathogenesis of dialysis dementia. Dialysis dementia is a unique neurologic complication of renal failure associated with chronic dialysis. While many questions remain about the pathophysiology of the disease, aluminum toxicity is probably the major factor in the pathogenesis of the dementia. Reducing dialysate aluminum levels and minimizing oral aluminum intake has markedly decreased the incidence of the disease. Deferoxamine, a chelating agent, is effective if it is given early; however, chronic use may lead to serious complications, although they are rare.

question: Which of the following is not an oppounistic infection in renal transplant patients in early (1-6 month) period?
exp: Oppounistic infection in renal transplantation < 1 Month Surgical site infection (SSI) with MRSA 1-6 month Pneumocystis jiroveci Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Hep B and C > 6 month Aspergillus Nocardia Bk virus (polyoma virus)

question: Which of the following is an absolute indication for hemodialysis in CKD?
exp: Absolute indication for Hemodialysis in CKD is Uremic pericarditis. This is due to propensity for hemorrhage in pericardial sac on account of uremia. The resultant cardiac tamponade will cause obstructive shock. Option A is managed with Soda Bicarbonate. Option C will cause pleural effusion but will not be life threatening as compared to pericarditis. Option D is managed with patiromer and potassium binding resins and only if it is life threatening values and refractory to medical therapy that dialysis is planned. Indications for Dialysis in CKD Pericarditis Fluid overload or pulmonary edema refractory to diuretics Accelerated HTN non-responsive to medication Progressive uremic encephalopathy Bleeding Diathesis

question: Non-oliguric renal failure occurs due to?
exp: Non-oliguric RF occur due to damage to collecting duct - So, water cannot be reabsorbed- H2O loss Cause: 1) Aminoglycosides
opc: Damage to ascending limb of Loop of Henle

question: A 28-year-old man has lenticonus and ESRD. His maternal uncle also died of similar illness. What is the diagnosis?
exp: Alpo Syndrome - 1. Classic AS - X-linked disorder- hematuria, sensorineural deafness, and lenticonus 2. A subtype of the X-linked form associated with diffuse leiomyomatosis 3. An autosomal recessive form 4. An autosomal dominant form. Both autosomal recessive and dominant forms can cause renal disease without deafness or lenticonus. Mutations in chains of type IV collagen (COL4. A3, COL4. A4, COL4. A5, and COL4. A6).

question: Which of the following is an absolute indication for hemodialysis?
exp: Indications for emergency dialysis is AEIOU-G Acidosis Acidosis refractory to medical therapy. If severe (pH < 7. 2 and refractory to HCO3 or unable to give HCO3 due to volume overload) or symptomatic (arrhythmias). Electrolytes Especially potassium with EKG changes. ONLY Intractable hyperkalemia (not Responding to Potassium-binding resins)requires dialysis Ingestions ause renal failure such as salicylates or ethylene glycol Overload Volume overload causing pulmonary edema. Uremia Confusion, pericarditis, seizures, Platelet dysfunction -Severe bleeding diathesis GFR GFR < 10 mL/min/1. 73 m2 (no benefit to initiating dialysis pre-emptively at a GFR of 10-14 mL/min per 1. 73 m2) Hyperkalemia per se is not an indication but Refractory hyperkalemia is an indication for dialysis.

question: A skin condition unique to Chronic Kidney Disease patients:
exp: Nephrogenic fibrosing dermopathy- A skin condition unique to CKD patients. It is progressive subcutaneous, especially on the arms and legs. The condition is similar to scleromyxedema and is seen very rarely in patients with CKD who have been exposed to the magnetic resonance contrast agent gadolinium. Current recommendations are that patients with CKD stage 3 (GFR 30-59 mL/min) should minimize exposure to gadolinium, and those with CKD stages 4-5 (GFR <30 mL/min) should avoid the use of gadolinium agents unless it is medically necessary.

question: Dialysis disequilibrium occurs due to:
exp: Complications of hemodialysis Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome Dialysis disequilibrium causes fluid shift in brain (Cerebral oedema, seizures) Symptoms- headache, nausea, emesis, vision, muscular twitching, disorientation, hypertension, tremors, and seizures. The condition tends to be self-limited and subside over several hours. Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome is attributed reverse urea effect.

question: Which of the following drug does not cause nephrotoxicity?
exp: Sirolimus is a non-nephrotoxic -m. TOR inhibitor with a long half-life of 62 hours. It was the first m. TOR inhibitor to be developed in solid organ transplantation as it inhibits cell proliferation.

question: Worsening of kidney function on contrast nephropathy is best evaluated with?
exp: S. Creatinine concentration usually begins to increase within 24 hours after contrast agent administration, peaks between days 3 and 5, and returns to baseline in 7-10 days. Serum cystatin C is also increased in patients with contrast-induced nephropathy. Nonspecific formed elements can appear in the urine, including renal tubular epithelial cells, pigmented granular casts, urate crystals, and debris. However, these urine findings do not correlate with severity.

question: Clinical features of C. R. F begin to appear when renal function is reduced to:
exp: Stage 1 and 2 of CKD are asymptomatic Symptoms beginning in Stage 3. Stage 3 begins at GFR of < 60ml/ min/ 1. 73m2 body surface area. Clinical features of CRF will develop when >50% or more of kidney parenchyma is destroyed. Renal injury, kidney has innate ability to maintain GFR-remaining healthy nephrons manifest hyperfiltration and compensatory hyperophy. This nephron adaptability allows for continued normal clearance of plasma solutes. The Plasma levels of substances such as urea and creatinine sta to show measurable increases only after total GFR has decreased to 50%.

question: Most common cause of death in patient on chronic hemodialysis:-
exp: Dialysis has || morbidity & moality as compared to kidney transplantation Complicationsof hemodialysis: 1. Hypotension (M/c) 2. M/c complication in recurrent hemodialysis = accelerated atherosclerosis 3. Dialysis dementia due to Ab2 amyloid 4. Carpal tunnel syndrome 5. Dialysis disequilibrium (Cerebral oedema, seizures) 6. Peripheral neuropathy / myopathy

question: Calciphylaxis is seen in CKD patients due to?
exp: Calciphylaxis Painful syndrome of calcification of the small blood vessels located within the fatty tissue and deeper layers of skin, blood clots and death of skin cells due to too little blood flow. Calciphylaxis is seen in CKD patients due to Warfarin

question: Atrophic kidney with papillary calcification in a garland pattern is seen in?
exp: Analgesic Nephropathy Long-term use of analgesic preparations containing phenacetin, aspirin, and caffeine Atrophic Kidney with Garland Pattern Because of decrease PG

question: Which of the following describes a CKD patient mentioned as G4 A2?
exp: Grades of Kidney Malfunction GFR 1 > 90 ml/ min / 1. 73 m2 2 60 - 89 ml 3 30 - 59 ml 4 15 - 29 ml 5 < 15 ml Albuminuria A1 3-30 mg/g A2 30-300 A3 > 300
opa: GFR between 15-29 ml/min/1. 73 m2 and albumin creatinine ratio of 30-300 mg/g
opb: GFR between 30-44 ml/min/1. 73 m2 and albumin creatinine ratio of 30-300 mg/g
opc: GFR between 45- 59 ml/min/1. 73 m2 and albumin creatinine ratio of 3-30 mg/g
opd: GFR between 60-89 ml/min/1. 73 m2 and albumin creatinine ratio of 3-30 mg/g

question: A 50-year-old diabetic patient is feeling unwell. On workup, his serum creatinine =5. 0mg% and blood urea= 125mg%. Urine MICRAL test is positive. Which of the following will be useful for this patient?
exp: * The ECG shows a heart rate of 125 bpm with extreme axis detion. * P waves are absent with bizarre wide complex q. RS in lead V4, V5, and V6 * Tall tented T waves which are seen with hyperkalemia, are present in all the leads. * The patient is a diabetic with deranged KFT. The patient is suffering from CKD and must be reaching stage 4-5 leading to hyperkalemia producing such pronounced ECG changes. * He is at risk of diastolic arrest of the heart. Hence the control of potassium is of paramount impoance in this patient. -Hyperkalemia in CKD patients responds to 1. Dietary restriction of potassium with use of kaliuretic diuretics 2. Potassium-binding resins like calcium resonium and sodium polystyrene can promote potassium loss GI Tract 3. Intractable hyperkalemia requires dialysis. A component should be managed with alkali supplementation if bicarbonate falls below 20 mmol/L.

question: What is not seen with uremic lung?
exp: Uremic lung Pathophysiology is based on uremia- induced increased permeability of pulmonary alveolar-capillary interfaces Leading to interstitial and intra-alveolar edema, atelectasis, alveolar hemorrhage, and pulmonary hyaline membrane formation. These changes are compounded by bleeding diathesis secondary to platelet dysfunction in advanced renal disease. The pulmonary symptoms and radiographic findings are reversible with hemodialysis

question: Which of the following is used for staging of CKD?
exp: e-GFR and albuminuria- used for staging of CKD
